ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We did virtual seminar and did presentations with classmates on our own time.

The class was set up as a M-F class with Monday, Wednesday, and Friday being synchronous and Tuesday and Thursday being asynchronous unless there was a test, which would take place during normal class time. The class was virtual yet with the small class size, we were still able to practice our Spanish speaking skills.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Presenting, learning to speak the language, and learning how to write in Spanish

The basics of communicating in Spanish at an introductory level. A few different tenses and methods of communicating. Present, Past Preterite, Past Perfect were learned. Cumulated in being able to read a short novel written fully in Spanish.

By taking this course, I was able to develop my writing and reading skills tremendously. I felt as if I was in a safe environment that allowed me to mess up and grow from those mistakes. The course gradually becomes more advanced but does so in a way that isn't threatening.
Learned the basics of grammar, vocabulary, sentence structure of spanish

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the course was done to the best of its ability while it was virtual. No weaknesses.

The strengths include the small class size and extremely interactive nature of the course and the ability to work closely with your peers and somewhat get to know them through assignments. The material is always engaging, though a weakness comes in the sheer quantity of assignments. Though necessary to maintain knowledge of a language, the number of assignments was extremely high in comparison to other classes.
We learned a lot of Spanish this semester so some review could be nice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We did alot of group work that kept me enganged.

The collaborative recordings were extremely effective in getting the students engaged with the material and their peers. The live classes were essential to learning a language, and recorded lectures would not be appropriate in a class of this nature. The use of Aventuras seemed more tedious than productive in my opinion.

Discussions were very engaging and there were many examples to practice new sentence structures or grammar. Sometimes the breakout rooms where we ask other students questions can get very repetitive and boring.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I learned alot and it was very fun.
I would recommend this course because it is a distributional requirement, though I warn them that the class is a commitment and a lot of work.
I would recommend this course to another student if they want to improve their Spanish. With this professor, one is able to practice their Spanish in an environment which promotes learning.
Yes, if one needs develop their Spanish skills.
If you want to learn Spanish, yes.
